review.title: On Robustness in Multilayer Interdependent Network
review.abstract: Critical Infrastructures like power and communication networks are highly interdependent on each other for their full functionality. Many significant research have been pursued to model the interdependency and failure analysis of these interdependent networks. However, most of these models fail to capture the complex interdependencies that might actually exist between the infrastructures. The \emph{Implicative Interdependency Model} that utilizes Boolean Logic to capture complex interdependencies was recently proposed which overcome the limitations of the existing models. A number of problems were studies based on this model. In this paper we study the \textit{Robustness} problem in Interdependent Power and Communication Network. The robustness is defined with respect to two parameters $K \in I^{+} \cup \{0\}$ and $\rho \in (0,1]$. We utilized the \emph{Implicative Interdependency Model} model to capture the complex interdependency between the two networks. The model classifies the interdependency relations into four cases. Computational complexity of the problem is analyzed for each of these cases. A polynomial time algorithm is designed for the first case that outputs the optimal solution. All the other cases are proved to be NP-complete. An in-approximability bound is provided for the third case. For the general case we formulate an Integer Linear Program to get the optimal solution and a polynomial time heuristic. The applicability of the heuristic is evaluated using power and communication network data of Maricopa County, Arizona. The experimental results showed that the heuristic almost always produced near optimal value of parameter $K$ for $\rho < 0.42$.

sections.heading: 6 Experimental Results
sections.text: We performed an experimental comparison between the heuristic and the optimal solution of the RIDN problem, using real-world datasets from GeoTel (www.geotel.com). The dataset contains 2, 690 cell towers, 7, 100 fiber-lit buildings and 42, 723 fiber-optic connections from Maricopa County, Arizona, USA. The data of the power grid comes from Platts (www.platts.com), containing 70 power plants and 470 transmission lines from the same circuit. We included four non-overlapping regions of Maricopa County. It should be noted that the unification of the regions does not cover the entire space. Units of the power and communication network for these four regions have been extracted. According to the notation, sets A and B contain units of the power and communication network, each unit of the power and communication network. The number of units in set A and set B is 29 and 19 units of region 1.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we propose the robustness problem in Multilayer Interdependency Network. Robustness in an IDN is defined with respect to two parameters K and ρ. The Implicative Interdependency Model is used to model the interdependence. The IIM model separates the interdependence relationships into four different cases. Analysis of the computational complexity of the robustness problem is performed with respect to these four cases. For the general form of the interdependence relationship, the problem is considered to be NP-complete. The optimal solution for the general case is determined from an ILP. Heuristics are designed to provide an overestimated K-parameter value for a given B. Finally, we compare the effectiveness of heuristics with the optimal solution using real data sets from Maricopa County, Arizona. Heuristics produced an optimal or near-optimal solution for a given B < 0.42.
